title: Project Revenge: why beating England at World Cup will mean so much to France
text:
As France’s players ambled a few steps from the plush lobby of the Hotel Nikko in Kumamoto to the bus waiting to take them to face Tonga, they did not appear like a team heading for a crucial World Cup match, let alone one in turmoil.

They walked out casually in small groups chatting and laughing, others seemingly day dreaming. It is perhaps no surprise they went on to scrape a 23-21 win which lacked tactical cohesion and intensity.

Yet once the job of securing a quarter-final spot was narrowly achieved and the topic of facing England raised, the players’ body language snapped into laser-focused intensity. Memories of being routed 44-8 in the Six Nations at Twickenham are spurring on this French...
description: As France’s players ambled a few steps from the plush lobby of the Hotel Nikko in Kumamoto to the bus waiting to take them to face Tonga, they did not appear like a team heading for a crucial World Cup match, let alone one in turmoil.
